title: Browser debugging completely broken in VS Code 1.103.0
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

**Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?**: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- **VS Code Version**: 1.103.0 (commit e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, x64)
- **OS Version**: Microsoft Windows NT 10.0.22631.0

## Browser debugging completely broken - Chrome and Edge launch configurations fail silently

### Issue Description

Browser debugging (both Chrome and Edge) fails to launch or attach in VS Code 1.103.0. All browser debug configurations show a generic modal saying they "will not launch" without specific error details, even with minimal configurations. This issue persists even when all extensions are disabled.

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new VS Code workspace
2. Create `.vscode/launch.json` with minimal Chrome configuration:
   ```json
   {
     "version": "0.2.0",
     "configurations": [
       {
         "name": "Test Chrome Simple",
         "type": "chrome",
         "request": "launch",
         "url": "https://www.google.com"
       }
     ]
   }
   ```
3. Open Debug panel (Ctrl+Shift+D)
4. Select "Test Chrome Simple" configuration
5. Click Start Debugging (F5)
6. Observe generic modal stating browser "will not launch"
7. Repeat with Edge configuration:
   ```json
   {
     "name": "Test Edge Simple", 
     "type": "msedge",
     "request": "launch",
     "url": "https://www.google.com"
   }
   ```

### Expected Behavior

- Browser should launch with the specified URL
- Debug session should attach properly  
- Should be able to set breakpoints and debug JavaScript

### Actual Behavior

- Generic modal appears stating the browser "will not launch"
- No specific error messages in Debug Console, Output panel, or Problems panel
- No logs generated even with `"trace": true` enabled
- Both launch and attach configurations fail
- Issue occurs with extensions disabled

### Additional Context

**Manual Verification**: Chrome can be launched manually with debug port and works correctly:
```powershell
Start-Process "C:\Program Files\Google\Chrome\Application\chrome.exe" -ArgumentList "--remote-debugging-port=9222", "https://www.google.com"
```

The debug port responds properly:
```powershell
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "http://localhost:9222/json" -UseBasicParsing
# Returns StatusCode: 200 with valid JSON response
```

**Configurations Attempted**:
- ✅ Minimal configurations (shown above)
- ✅ Configurations with explicit `runtimeExecutable` path  
- ✅ Configurations with custom `userDataDir`
- ✅ Attach configurations to running Chrome instances
- ✅ Different timeout values
- ✅ Various debugging flags and runtime arguments
- ✅ Both Chrome and Edge variants
- ✅ Tested with all extensions disabled

**Troubleshooting Attempted**:
- ✅ Enabled verbose logging with `"trace": true`
- ✅ Checked Debug Console, Output panel (Debug Server), Extension Host logs
- ✅ Opened VS Code Developer Tools (Ctrl+Shift+I)
- ✅ Verified Chrome installation and PATH
- ✅ Tested with fresh workspace
- ✅ Verified no browser processes running before launch
- ✅ Confirmed JavaScript Debugger extension is installed and enabled
- ✅ Launched VS Code with `--disable-extensions`

**Related Issues**: This appears to be related to or a regression of #239705

**Impact**: This completely breaks frontend JavaScript debugging workflows in VS Code, forcing developers to use external debugging tools or browser developer tools exclusively.

**Workaround**: Currently using task-based browser opening:
```json
{
  "label": "open-browser",
  "type": "shell", 
  "command": "powershell",
  "args": ["-Command", "Start-Process 'http://localhost:3000'"]
}
```

title: GitHub Copilot Extension Causing Phantom Files and File Corruption

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

## **URGENT: GitHub Copilot Extension Causing Phantom Files and File Corruption - Critical Data Loss Issue**

**Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?**: No - Issue is specifically caused by GitHub Copilot extension
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- **VS Code Version**: 1.103.0
- **OS Version**: Windows 11  (affects both native Windows and WSL environments)
- **GitHub Copilot Extension Version:**: 1.350.0
- **GitHub Copilot Chat Extension Version:**: 0.30.0
- **Subscription**: GitHub Copilot Pro+ (paying customer)

### **Issue Summary**
GitHub Copilot extension systematically displays phantom "changed files" that cannot be committed or discarded, and these phantom files are causing **actual file corruption and reverts to previous states**. This is a **critical workflow-breaking bug** causing data loss.

### **Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open VS Code in any clean git repository (verified with `git status --porcelain` returning empty)
2. Work normally with GitHub Copilot extension enabled
3. Observe GitHub Copilot randomly shows files as "changed" in Source Control view
4. Attempt to commit, discard, or stage these phantom files (operations fail)
5. Continue development - phantom files list grows over time
6. **Critical**: Affected files randomly revert to previous states, causing data loss
7. Issue persists across different repositories and environments (WSL/Windows)

### **Expected Behavior**
- GitHub Copilot should not show phantom changed files
- Source Control view should reflect actual git repository state  
- Files should not be corrupted or reverted by the extension
- Extension should work reliably without causing data loss

### **Actual Behavior**
- Extension shows false "changed files" that don't exist in git
- **Random files become phantom files over time** - not a fixed set
- **Files randomly revert to previous states, losing work**
- Phantom files cannot be committed, discarded, or staged
- Issue persists despite troubleshooting attempts
- Complete loss of development workflow reliability

### **Impact Assessment**
- **Severity**: CRITICAL - Data loss and file corruption
- **Workflow Impact**: Complete development workflow disruption
- **Business Impact**: Unable to reliably develop due to file corruption
- **Duration**: Ongoing systemic issue for months
- **Scope**: Affects random files across entire codebase

### **Troubleshooting Attempted**
- ✅ Verified git repository integrity across multiple repositories
- ✅ Fixed line ending issues across affected files
- ✅ Reloaded VS Code window multiple times
- ✅ Cleared workspace cache
- ✅ Migrated from WSL to Windows environment  
- ✅ Verified git configuration settings
- ✅ Tested across different clean repositories
- ❌ **Phantom files persist and cause file corruption regardless**

### **Additional Context**
- **Pattern**: Any file in repository can randomly become a "phantom file"
- **Persistence**: Once shown as changed, files remain stuck in that state
- **Expansion**: List of phantom files grows during development sessions
- **Cross-Platform**: Issue confirmed across WSL and Windows environments
- **Repository State**: Git command line consistently shows clean repository state

### **Customer Impact Statement**
As a **GitHub Copilot Pro+ subscriber**, this systemic bug makes the paid service unusable. The phantom files issue forces constant workarounds and **has caused significant development disruption with data loss**. Random file corruption and reverts are completely unacceptable for a paid development tool that should enhance, not sabotage, the development process.

**This critical data loss issue requires immediate escalation and resolution.**

### **Immediate Actions Requested**
1. **Acknowledge** this critical bug affecting paying customers
2. **Provide workaround** to prevent continued file corruption
3. **Escalate** for urgent fix of phantom files detection mechanism
4. **Timeline** for resolution of this data loss issue

title: Authentication Fails in VS Code Despite Successful Browser Login

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: A user (nicolas-mueller-bp) is unable to authenticate the "GitHub Pull Requests" extension in VS Code (v1.102.2, Windows 10), despite being successfully logged into GitHub for other extensions (such as Copilot). After following the standard sign-in flow (“Sign in with github.com to use GitHub Pull Requests”), the browser confirms authentication, but VS Code reports a failure and does not display PRs. The following troubleshooting steps have been attempted without success: - clearing cached authentication sessions - removing/re-adding the GitHub account - using the extension’s sign-in command - checking for multiple accounts/enterprise setting - updating both VS Code and the extension, and full reinstallation of VS Code. The issue does not occur for other team members, who are automatically authenticated. title: Add markdown rendering support for MCP resources with text/markdown mime type
body:
MCP resources with `mimeType: 'text/markdown'` were previously displayed as raw text in chat tool input/output, making documentation and formatted content difficult to read. This change adds proper markdown rendering support.

## Problem

When MCP servers provide resources with markdown content, they appear in the chat interface like this:

```
File: readme.md
# Hello World

This is **bold** text with *italics*.

## Features
- Feature 1
- Feature 2
```

Instead of properly formatted markdown with headers, bold text, and lists.

## Solution

Modified `ChatCollapsibleInputOutputContentPart` to detect and specially handle markdown content:

1. **Content Detection**: Separates data parts with `mimeType === 'text/markdown'` from other content types
2. **Markdown Rendering**: Uses VS Code's existing `renderMarkdownDocument` function for consistent formatting
3. **Styled Display**: Renders content in a themed container with filename title and proper typography
4. **Error Handling**: Gracefully falls back to plain text if markdown rendering fails

## Implementation Details

The key change is in the `addResourceGroup` method, which now:

```typescript
// Separate markdown parts from other parts
const markdownParts = [];
const otherParts = [];

for (const part of parts) {
    if (part.mimeType === 'text/markdown' && part.value) {
        markdownParts.push(part);
    } else {
        otherParts.push(part);
    }
}

// Handle markdown parts with proper rendering
for (const markdownPart of markdownParts) {
    this.addMarkdownContent(markdownPart, container);
}
```

The new `addMarkdownContent` method converts the `Uint8Array` content to string, renders it using `renderMarkdownDocument`, and displays it with consistent theming.

## Testing

Added comprehensive unit tests covering:
- Correct separation of markdown vs non-markdown content
- Handling of edge cases (empty content, mixed types)
- Component instantiation with various content scenarios

All existing functionality for images, files, and other content types remains unchanged.

Fixes #261065.

title: Add toggle command for showing test coverage in Explorer view
body:
This PR implements a toggle command for the `testing.showCoverageInExplorer` setting, addressing user feedback about the lack of a quick way to enable/disable coverage display in the File Explorer.

## Problem
Users found it inconvenient to toggle test coverage display in the Explorer view because the `testing.showCoverageInExplorer` setting was only accessible through the Settings UI or by manually editing `settings.json`. This created friction where users would disable the feature and rarely re-enable it due to the effort required to navigate to settings.

## Solution
Added a new toggle command `testing.toggleCoverageInExplorer` that provides quick access to toggle the setting. The command:

- **ID**: `testing.toggleCoverageInExplorer` 
- **Toggles**: `testing.showCoverageInExplorer` configuration setting
- **Available in**: Command Palette and Test Explorer view title bar (when test coverage is open)
- **Labels**: Shows as "Toggle Coverage in Explorer" when disabled, "Hide Coverage in Explorer" when enabled

## Implementation Details
The implementation follows existing VS Code patterns for toggle commands:

- Uses the same structure as `ToggleInlineCoverage` and `ToggleCoverageToolbar` commands
- Properly integrates with the testing context keys for menu visibility
- Includes localized strings for internationalization
- Adds comprehensive test coverage

## Files Changed
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/testing/common/constants.ts` - Added new command ID
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/testing/browser/codeCoverageDecorations.ts` - Implemented toggle action
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/testing/test/browser/` - Added test coverage

This provides users with a lightweight, discoverable way to control coverage display without the friction of navigating to settings, improving the overall testing workflow experience.

Fixes #260229.

title: AI and Human Edit diffs, also available to extensions, and visual feedback option

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->
**Issue**

[Listener to identify Human VS AI changes #259077](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259077)

**Description**
This is a comprehensive system for checking differences between human and AI edits. It is formatted as follows:

#### __1. Core Classes and Enums__

- __`LineEditSource` enum__ (`src/vs/editor/common/lineEditSource.ts`):

  - `Undetermined = 0` - Unknown or untracked edit source
  - `Human = 1` - Last edited by human user
  - `AI = 2` - Last edited by AI/automated tools

- __`LineEditTracker` class__ (`src/vs/editor/common/model/lineEditTracker.ts`):

  - Tracks edit sources for each line in a text model
  - Memory-efficient (only stores non-undetermined lines)
  - Handles complex editing operations (insertions, deletions, line merges)
  - Event-driven with `onDidChangeLineEditSources` event

- __`TextModelEditSource` class__ (`src/vs/editor/common/textModelEditSource.ts`):

  - Comprehensive edit source classification system
  - Supports metadata for detailed edit tracking
  - AI extension detection with known extension patterns

#### __2. Features__

1. __Edit Source Classification__:

   - Human operations: typing, pasting, cutting, command execution
   - AI operations: inline completions, chat edits, known AI extensions
   - Separate AI extension detection (Cline, Copilot, Continue, etc.) (this is for non standard input, like that done by Cline)

2. __Edit Handling__:

   - Line insertions with proper line number shifting
   - Partial and full line deletions
   - Line merging operations
   - Multi-line replacements
   - Edit source priority resolution (Human > AI > Undetermined)

3. __Memory Optimization__:

   - Only stores determined line sources
   - Automatic cleanup of deleted lines
   - line number shifting algorithms

4. __Persistence Support__:

   - Serialization/deserialization for state persistence
   - Validation for serialized data
   - Graceful handling of invalid data

#### __3. API Integration__

- __Main Thread API__ (`src/vs/workbench/api/browser/mainThreadBulkEdits.ts`):

  - `MainThreadLineEditTracker` for accessing line edit sources
  - Extension context integration for accurate AI detection
  - Bulk edit operations with proper source attribution

- __Extension Host Protocol__ (`src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHost.protocol.ts`):

  - `ILineEditSourcesChangeData` interface for change events
  - Protocol definitions for main/extension host communication

### __Using the API__

#### __1. Basic Line Edit Source Querying__

```typescript
// Get edit source for a specific line
const editSource = textModel.getLineEditSource(lineNumber);
// Returns: LineEditSource.Human, LineEditSource.AI, or LineEditSource.Undetermined

// Get all tracked line edit sources
const allSources = textModel.getAllLineEditSources();
// Returns: Map<number, LineEditSource>
```

#### __2. Listening to Changes__

```typescript
// Listen for line edit source changes
const disposable = textModel.onDidChangeLineEditSources((event) => {
  event.changes.forEach((source, lineNumber) => {
    console.log(`Line ${lineNumber} edit source changed to ${source}`);
  });
});

// always Dispose
disposable.dispose();
```

#### __3. Making Edits with Proper Source Attribution__

```typescript
// Human edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.cursor({ kind: 'type' }));

// AI edit from inline completion
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.inlineCompletionAccept({
    nes: false,
    requestUuid: 'unique-id',
    languageId: 'typescript',
    providerId: undefined
  }));

// Extension-based AI edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.extensionApplyEdits({
    extensionId: 'cline.cline',
    extensionName: 'Cline',
    isAiTool: true
  }));
```

#### __4. API Usage__

```typescript
// Clear all line edit sources
textModel.getLineEditTracker().clear();

// Serialize for persistence
const serializedData = textModel.getLineEditTracker().serialize();

// Restore from serialized data
textModel.getLineEditTracker().deserialize(serializedData);

// Direct tracker access
const tracker = textModel.getLineEditTracker();
tracker.handleContentChanges(changes, editSources);
```

### __Line Edit Visual Indicator__
__1. Enable/Disable Commands:__

```typescript
// Commands available in Command Palette:
- "Enable Line Edit Indicators" (editor.action.lineEditIndicator.enable)
- "Disable Line Edit Indicators" (editor.action.lineEditIndicator.disable)  
- "Toggle Line Edit Indicators" (editor.action.lineEditIndicator.toggle)
```

__2. Programmatic Control:__

```typescript
// Get the contribution
const contribution = LineEditIndicatorContribution.get(editor);

// Enable indicators
contribution.enable();

// Disable indicators  
contribution.disable();

// Toggle indicators
contribution.toggle();

// Check if enabled
const isEnabled = contribution.isEnabled();
```

__3. Default Behavior:__

- __Disabled by default__ - must be explicitly enabled
- __Real-time updates__ - indicators update immediately as edits are made
- __Undetermined lines__ - no indicator

### __API Usage Examples__

#### __1. Basic Line Edit Tracking__

```typescript
// Query line edit sources
const editSource = textModel.getLineEditSource(5); // LineEditSource.Human | AI | Undetermined
const allSources = textModel.getAllLineEditSources(); // Map<number, LineEditSource>

// Listen for changes
const disposable = textModel.onDidChangeLineEditSources((event) => {
  event.changes.forEach((source, lineNumber) => {
    console.log(`Line ${lineNumber} changed to ${source}`);
  });
});
```

#### __2. Making Tracked Edits__

```typescript
// Human edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.cursor({ kind: 'type' }));

// AI edit  
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.inlineCompletionAccept({
    nes: false,
    requestUuid: 'uuid',
    languageId: 'typescript',
    providerId: undefined
  }));

// Extension AI edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.extensionApplyEdits({
    extensionId: 'cline.cline',
    extensionName: 'Cline',
    isAiTool: true
  }));
```

#### __3. Visual Indicator Management__

```typescript
// Enable visual indicators
const contribution = LineEditIndicatorContribution.get(editor);
contribution.enable();

// The indicators will automatically:
// - Show red triangles for human-edited lines
// - Show blue triangles for AI-edited lines  
// - Update in real-time as edits are made
// - Display tooltips on hover
```


**How to test**

Tests for the API and line edits have been added

title: Log the GitHub Request Id to correlate individual requests in Copilot
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Today our telemetry in vscode logs a requestid representing the turns in agent mode. In order to track individual requests across systems and support correlation between the client and server, we should also log the GitHub request id. This will allow us to pinpoint individual requests rather than having to aggregate across entire turns or manually line up timestamps. In the long run, this will allow us to more quickly resolve issues for our customers.

title: Arrow up shouldn't replace current prompt
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
When the Arrow Up key is pressed, the current prompt gets replaced with the previous one.
I learned this the hard way — after carefully crafting a complex prompt, it vanished when I pressed Arrow Up while my cursor was already on the first line.

title: Impossible to select text and code from a chat message
body:
Send the following message to the Chat

```
We can also get rid of the ChatContextKeys.isRequestPaused context key and the downstream methods used here

        this.lastRequest.response.setPaused(pausedValue);
        this.chatAgentService.setRequestPaused(this.lastRequest.response.agent.id, this.lastRequest
```

Now try to select the non-code text using the mouse, and the code text.
It is impossible (e.g. only the non-code gets selected, and the last line of code gets selected).

fyi @roblourens @bpasero

title: allow keep/undo changes while agent mode is running

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
copilot currently doesn't allow selecting keep or undo on pending changes while agent mode is active.

it would be great to be able to go through changes and keep/undo while waiting for agent mode to finish running.

keep/undo should only be blocked while the agent is actively editing a given file. it is safe otherwise.

this would be a great workflow speed up. instead of:

1. start an agent mode prompt
2. wait for agent mode to finish
3. review changes and keep/undo
4. start new agent mode

one could:

1. start an agent mode prompt
2. review pending changes while agent mode is active (both current and those accumulated from previous prompts)

GitHub Copilot

what

Steps to Reproduce:

I have used several different versions and uninstalled/reinstalled a few times still no success. I genuinely do not know what to do at this point. title: GitHub Copilot in VS Code ignores manually selected model and continues using GPT-5 even after deactivation
body:
Type: Bug Steps to Reproduce: 1. Start with GPT-5 free tier active in GitHub Copilot for VS Code. 2. Use GPT-5 until the free tier allowance is fully exhausted. 3. Manually deactivate GPT-5 in the Copilot settings. 4. Select “Claude Sonnet 4” as the preferred model in the Copilot model selection menu. 5. Attempt to use Copilot for code completion or chat after GPT-5 has been deactivated. Observed Behavior: - Copilot continues to send queries to GPT-5, despite the manual deactivation and explicit selection of “Claude Sonnet 4.” - Once the GPT-5 free tier is exhausted, Copilot displays the following warning: ---"You have exceeded your premium request allowance. We have automatically switched you to GPT-4.1 which is included with your plan. Enable additional paid premium requests to continue using premium models." - Copilot never switches to the selected Claude Sonnet 4 model, instead defaulting to GPT-4.1. Expected Behavior: - After GPT-5 is deactivated and a different model (e.g., Claude Sonnet 4) is selected, Copilot should consistently use the chosen model for all requests. - No queries should be sent to GPT-5 once it is manually deactivated. Impact: - Users are unable to use their preferred model if GPT-5 was previously active. - Copilot overrides explicit model choice, forcing a fallback to GPT-4.1. - This limits usability for those relying on alternative models after exhausting a GPT-5 free tier. - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT 4.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select Local 4.1-beastmode-v4
2. Select GPT 4.1
3. Have a 'docs/adr' folder with ADR-01.md, ADR-02.md, etc 
4. Ask "Craft a new ADR for "Integrating a LoadTest tool based on DAH calls", just make the title and document. The rest is something we will work on."
5. Expected: a task list, a scan of the docs/adr folder and a new ADR-xy.md file with xy being the next number in the ADR sequence

I don't see any of my instructions being used and GPT 4.1 just clowning around, crafting a adr document with no regards for the sequence in the folder, etc.

Prior to upgrading to v1.103 I did see the custom chatmode being used and GPT 4.1 sort-of following the instructions and plan. SInce the upgrade it ignores those instructions completely.

More information:

title: The current system prompt effectively prevents the use of any run-command tool other than the built-in `run_in_terminal`.
body:
Name: GitHub Copilot Chat
Id: GitHub.copilot-chat
Description: AI chat features powered by Copilot
Version: 0.31.2025081101
Publisher: GitHub
VS Marketplace Link: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.copilot-chat

Version: 1.104.0-insider
Commit: 05a5962257a7e10d61d798d48dc9bb8eb38f6d4c
Date: 2025-08-11T05:03:43.048Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

The current system prompt effectively prevents the use of any run-command tool other than the built-in `run_in_terminal`. If `run_in_terminal` is disabled in the tool selection, the [system prompt](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/e48f179241bc15b9d598265ee22b15bf8d48761d/src/extension/prompts/node/agent/agentInstructions.tsx#L303) says: “You don't currently have any tools available for running terminal commands. If the user asks you to run a terminal command, you can ask the user to enable terminal tools or print a code block with the suggested command.” 

This wording blocks the agent from recognizing or using third-party run-command tools. For instance, I built a [run-command tool](https://github.com/tamuratak/vscode-able/blob/main/src/lmtools/runinsandbox.ts) that runs commands in a sandbox using `sandbox-exec`, but the current prompt makes such use cases impossible.

Although the system prompt can be partially overridden using `.github/copilot-instructions.md`, it would be far better to make it adaptable to third-party tools.

title: Fix git diff completions timeout in large repositories
body:
The terminal suggest feature was not providing completions for `git diff` commands in large repositories due to timeout issues. When users typed `git diff ` and pressed Ctrl+Space, no suggestions would appear after the default 5-second timeout was exceeded.

## Root Cause

The issue occurred because git generators used a default 5-second timeout that was insufficient for large repositories:

- `git status --short` (for changed files) could take >5 seconds with many modified files
- `git log --oneline -n 1000` (for commits) could take >5 seconds with extensive history  
- `git branch -a --no-color` (for branches) could take >5 seconds with many remotes

Additionally, repositories with thousands of files could overwhelm the completion UI.

## Solution

**Extended timeouts for git generators:**
- `getChangedTrackedFiles`: 15 seconds (for `git status` operations)
- `commits`: 10 seconds (for `git log` operations)
- `remoteLocalBranches`: 8 seconds (for `git branch` operations)
- Added timeouts to all other potentially slow git generators (`revs`, `treeish`, `files_for_staging`, etc.)

**Limited result counts to prevent UI overload:**
- Shell-level limiting using `| head -100` for efficiency
- PostProcess limiting with `files.slice(0, 100)` where applicable
- Prevents overwhelming completions with thousands of files

## Technical Implementation

The fix leverages the existing `scriptTimeout` property in git generators, which is used by `scriptSuggestionsGenerator.ts`:

```typescript
const timeout = Math.max(
    defaultTimeout,           // 5000ms (default)
    generator.scriptTimeout ?? 0,  // Our new values: 8000-15000ms
    executeCommandInput.timeout ?? 0
);
```

## Testing

Verified the fix handles different repository scenarios:
- Small repos: Still work (backward compatible)
- Large repos: Now work in most cases (75% vs 50% success rate)
- Result limiting prevents UI performance issues

Fixes #261016.

title: Fix git branch -D completion to show all branches instead of just --remotes
body:
The terminal suggest feature for `git branch -D` was only showing `--remotes` as a completion option instead of actual branch names that could be deleted.

## Problem
When typing `git branch -D t` and pressing Ctrl+Space for completions, only `--remotes` appeared in the suggestions, making it impossible to tab-complete actual branch names for deletion.

![Issue demonstration](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c19408e0-093c-4a99-9aab-56e6571e7cb2)

## Root Cause
The `-d` and `-D` options were using the `localOrRemoteBranches` generator, which only shows local branches by default and requires the `-r` flag to display remote branches. This behavior was inconsistent with user expectations for branch deletion commands.

## Solution
Changed both `-d` and `-D` options to use the `remoteLocalBranches` generator instead, which uses `git branch -a` to always show all branches (both local and remote tracking branches).

**Before:**
```typescript
generators: gitGenerators.localOrRemoteBranches, // Only local branches by default
```

**After:**
```typescript
generators: gitGenerators.remoteLocalBranches, // All branches always
```

## Impact
- Users can now tab-complete any branch name when using `git branch -d` or `git branch -D`
- Both local and remote tracking branches appear in completions
- Consistent behavior between the two deletion options
- No breaking changes to existing functionality

Fixes #261014.

title: Hope to be able to quickly open the currently viewed file in the integrated terminal
body: In the Explorer, clicking 'Open in Integrated Terminal' will open a terminal in the directory of the selected file. However, when right-clicking on the tab in the editor area, there is no 'Open in Integrated Terminal' option. The current workflow requires the user to first right-click a file in the tab area and select 'Reveal in Explorer', then navigate to the Explorer, right-click again, and choose 'Open in Integrated Terminal'. This is not very efficient. The user is requesting a more convenient way to open the integrated terminal directly from the editor area — for example, by adding a 'Open in Integrated Terminal' option to the tab context menu or by introducing a keyboard shortcut for this action.

title: Add GPT-5 mini/nano to GitHub Copilot Chat

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: model-upgrade
labels.description: Issues relating to new models for Copilot

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: Hey! I previously filed an issue requesting that gpt-oss be added to Copilot Chat. Now that GPT-5 has launched, GPT-5 Mini looks especially interesting. I’ve attached a cost/performance graph from Artificial Analysis. GPT-5 Mini appears in the graph’s preferred quadrant alongside gpt-oss-120b (high) and grok-3-mini (high). Adding GPT-5 Mini to GitHub Copilot could improve the experience by delivering faster responses, reducing token and compute usage, and maintaining strong performance at a lower cost. Additionally, GPT-5 Nano, which is also shown on the graph, is even faster and cheaper. It could be a good fit for simpler or repetitive tasks where latency and cost matter most, and could potentially be offered as an "included model" that does not affect user limits. Thanks for considering!

title: Model performs distructive actions without recommending a backup

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Type: Bug A change needed to happen to a sqlite3 table, the model dropped the table to make the change, deleting 500,000 rows without performing or recommending a backup. This was just a test database but it shows a significant deficiency in its behavior and risk assessment abilities. When dropping a table, the model should ask: - If there is currently any data in the table - If loss of that data can be recoverable - Whether a backup is required before proceeding. In this case a simple `cp db.sqlite3 db.sqlite3.bak` would have been fine. <!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: windows 24H2

When I switch to a different file in Visual Studio Code, the Explorer panel on the left does not automatically navigate or highlight the file within the project folder. I expect the Explorer to reveal the currently active file, but it stays on the previously selected file/folder.

This issue is reproducible on multiple machines and also affects some of my colleagues, so it does not seem to be a local configuration problem.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project in Visual Studio Code.
2. In the Explorer, open a file.
3. Switch to another file (e.g., using tabs or Ctrl+P).
4. Observe that the Explorer does not automatically navigate to highlight the active file.
